**Chain mail** is a type of [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

[Orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") characters in a role that starts with chain mail receive [orcish chain mail](/wiki/Orcish_chain_mail "Orcish chain mail") instead[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) - currently, there are no roles that make use of this substitution, as no roles start with chain mail.

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), used armor dealerships and antique weapon outlets can sell chain mail.

[Chieftains](/wiki/Chieftain "Chieftain"), [pages](/wiki/Page "Page"), [roshi](/wiki/Roshi "Roshi"), and [warriors](/wiki/Warrior "Warrior") have a 2⁄3 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") chain mail.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") [barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian_\(player_monster\) "Barbarian (player monster)"), [knights](/wiki/Knight_\(player_monster\) "Knight (player monster)"), [priests](/wiki/Priest_\(player_monster\) "Priest (player monster)"), and [valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie_\(player_monster\) "Valkyrie (player monster)") have an effective 18⁄155 chance (roughly \~11.61%) of forcing chain mail in place of their initial body armor.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As part of [commit 20cbadcf](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/20cbadcf85544cf9d0c3f4e4200b2800bab49c8e) - which strengthens [quest leaders](/wiki/Quest_leader "Quest leader") and makes it so that killing them no longer makes the game [unwinnable](/wiki/Unwinnable "Unwinnable") - the [Barbarian quest](/wiki/Barbarian_quest "Barbarian quest") leader [Pelias](/wiki/Pelias "Pelias") generates with +5 chain mail.

## Description

While worn, chain mail provides 5 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and [MC1](/wiki/MC1 "MC1").

## Strategy

Chain mail is a decent set of armor, though it is heavy and blocks [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting"). Roles looking to shore up their AC early can make good use of a set of chain mail until they can obtain [dragon scale mail](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail") or else find other armor that is lighter (e.g., [dwarvish mithril-coat](/wiki/Dwarvish_mithril-coat "Dwarvish mithril-coat") and [elven mithril-coat](/wiki/Elven_mithril-coat "Elven mithril-coat")) or more conducive to spellcasting (e.g., [studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor")).

## History

Chain mail first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial list of armor for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.2.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.3 "NetHack 3.2.3"), the [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") role starts with +0 chain mail - [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0") and later versions replace this with the [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Mail (armour)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mail_\(armour\) "wikipedia:Mail (armour)")***

Chain mail is made of small metal rings interlocked to form a mesh, and was widely used in Europe, Asia, and North Africa, from pre-Roman times until as late as the 19th century. In medieval sources, this type of armor was described simply as "mail" - the use of the term to describe other types of armor (and the invention of "chain mail" to distinguish it from those) began in 19th-century historical fiction.

The stats for chain mail in *NetHack* are derived from its appearance in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the [Undead Slayer](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer") has a 1⁄4 chance of starting with chain mail as their body armor. Orcish Undead Slayers that would start with chain mail as their body armor receive orcish chain mail instead, making use of the existing substitution.

A set of chain mail appears on the goal level of the [Yeoman quest](/wiki/Yeoman_quest "Yeoman quest"), placed on the [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar") of the lawful [temple](/wiki/Temple "Temple").

[Upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") orcish chain mail will produce regular chain mail, and vice versa.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), chain mail grants 2 base AC, 3 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") and MC1 while worn, and its weight is reduced to 150 aum.

[Dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") [Binders](/wiki/Binder_\(dNetHack_role\) "Binder (dNetHack role)") always start with [thoroughly rusty](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") chain mail, while Dwarven and female [half-dragon](/wiki/Half-dragon_\(starting_race\) "Half-dragon (starting race)") [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble") will always start with standard chain mail. All non-[Incantifier](/wiki/Incantifier_\(dNetHack_starting_race\) "Incantifier (dNetHack starting race)") Knights start the game with chain mail - incantifier Knights are given a [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe") instead.

[Soldier ants](/wiki/Soldier_ant "Soldier ant") and [queen bees](/wiki/Queen_bee "Queen bee") generated on the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Law_quest_\(dNetHack\) "Law quest (dNetHack)") have an effective 3⁄25 chance of generating with chain mail.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), [Croesus](/wiki/Croesus "Croesus") has a 7⁄8 chance of generating with [gold](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") chain mail.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), [aligned champions](/wiki/Champion_\(monster\) "Champion (monster)") and [ronin](/wiki/Ronin "Ronin") have a 1⁄3 chance of generating with chain mail. Chain mail may also be generated as part of various kits for player monsters, including [centaurs](/index.php?title=Centaur_\(monster_attribute\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Centaur (monster attribute) (page does not exist)") (who can wear body armor in EvilHack).

Chain mail can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining two sets of [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail"). Chain mail can be used to forge a few items:

- Chain mail can be combined with [splint mail](/wiki/Splint_mail "Splint mail") to create [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail").
- Chain mail can be combined with [scale mail](/wiki/Scale_mail "Scale mail") to create splint mail.
- Chain mail can be combined with a [dwarvish roundshield](/wiki/Dwarvish_roundshield "Dwarvish roundshield") to create [dwarvish chain mail](/wiki/Dwarvish_chain_mail "Dwarvish chain mail").
- Chain mail can be combined with an [elven shield](/wiki/Elven_shield "Elven shield") to create [elven chain mail](/wiki/Elven_chain_mail "Elven chain mail").

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") Undead Slayers that would start with chain mail start with [low boots](/wiki/Low_boots "Low boots") instead, while [tortle](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)") Undead Slayers receive [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves") in place of chain mail.

In addition to EvilHack details and forging recipes, upgrading orcish chain mail will produce regular chain mail and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM.

## References

2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 288](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L288)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 174](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L174): *1⁄2 for barbarians and other mentioned roles to get random body armor within the range of objects from plate mail to chain mail in objects.c, using normal generation odds*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 201](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L201): *body armor for knights*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 215](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L215): *body armor for priests*
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 242](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mplayer.c#L242): *body armor for valkyries*
